lines.text: Sometimes with all the wear and tear of use (especially if you have 19 of them working in a robot...), servo gears need to be replaced. It's a much cheaper alternative to buying a new servo. Here's how to do it!
lines.text_raw: Sometimes with all the wear and tear of use (especially if you have 19 of them working in a robot...), servo gears need to be replaced. It's a much cheaper alternative to buying a new servo. Here's how to do it!

lines.text: Start by taking out all the screws from the bottom of the case.
lines.text_raw: Start by taking out all the screws from the bottom of the case.

lines.text: Take off any stickers on the outside; these might also hold together the different plastic parts of the case.
lines.text_raw: Take off any stickers on the outside; these might also hold together the different plastic parts of the case.

lines.text: We're specifically going to look at changing the highlighted gear. It's the one that breaks 95% of the time. The other gears are replaced in a similar manner.
lines.text_raw: We're specifically going to look at changing the highlighted gear. It's the one that breaks 95% of the time. The other gears are replaced in a similar manner.

lines.text: Wiggle out the two gears that are on the same metal rod, and remove them.
lines.text_raw: Wiggle out the two gears that are on the same metal rod, and remove them.

lines.text: Place one of the replacement gears in their place.
lines.text_raw: Place one of the replacement gears in their place.

lines.text: Put the servo back together in the reverse order that you took it apart.
lines.text_raw: Put the servo back together in the reverse order that you took it apart.

guide.summary: Replacing the gears on a 9g Servo, specifically the ArcBotics 9g Black Gear Servo.
